items.title: Live: Victoria faces 'changing conditions' as fires rage on with 300 buildings lost, one person dead
items.description: Firefighters continue to battle fires across the state after the grim news that a person had been found dead and at least 390,000 hectares burnt. Follow live.

items.title: 'This was a safe place': Harcourt's heart in ruins but community stands strong
items.description: In a region famed for its lush pastoral farmland, locals thought Harcourt was less likely to be hit than neighbouring bush towns Castlemaine and Barkers Creek.

items.title: More than the US and UK, the Taliban has an issue with Australia
items.description: The Taliban's chief spokesman agreed to an unscripted, sit-down interview with me, there was just one non-negotiable condition, writes Meghna Bali.

items.title: 'The hero of Bondi Junction' stabbing attack diagnosed with rare cancer
items.description: NSW Police Inspector Amy Scott, who was praised for bringing the Westfield Bondi Junction stabbing attack to an end, has been diagnosed with a rare and aggressive form of breast cancer.

items.title: 'These ICE agents are here for sport': Why immigration agents surged into Minneapolis
items.description: Minneapolis had been the target of a massive immigration enforcement operation in the weeks leading up to Renee Nicole Good's death. Now, the shooting has opened old wounds.

items.title: Live: Golden Globes underway with Jacob Elordi nominated twice
items.description: The 83rd Golden Globe awards have arrived and a slew of Australian stars will be hoping to win big, including Frankenstein's Jacob Elordi. Follow live.

items.title: At least 500 killed in Iran protests as Trump weighs intervention
items.description: The US-based Human Rights Activists News Agency says a further 10,600 people have been arrested as Iran's theocratic government attempts to crack down on the demonstrations.

items.title: Heavy rainfall batters Queensland as ex-Cyclone Koji moves inland
items.description: Severe weather warnings for "locally intense rainfall" are in place from Mackay to Gladstone and inland after several people were rescued from floodwaters.

items.title: Walking through post-festival camp full of abandoned gear feels like 'shopping'
items.description: With campsite trash accounting for more than half of the rubbish accumulated at music festivals, there are calls for a "cultural shift" in the behaviour of those attending.

items.title: Live: ACCC likely to sue Coles, Woolies for price gouging — report
items.description: The competition watchdog will use new powers to go after the big supermarkets in court, according to a report today, as the ASX makes gains after record highs in US, Europe and UK markets. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

items.title: Ozempic-like drug to be listed on PBS for people with severe obesity
items.description: The cost of weight loss drug Wegovy will soon be massively subsidised for Australians with severe obesity who have had a stroke or heart attack.

items.title: Why there are no Michelin-starred restaurants in Australia
items.description: If you're a food lover, chances are you've heard of the Michelin Guide – you may have even dined at a Michelin-starred restaurant, but not here in Australia.

items.title: How 'hidden thoughts' can be a sign of OCD in some people
items.description: Everyone experiences intrusive thoughts, and most people can brush them off without a worry. But what happens when those intrusive thoughts become inescapable?

items.title: Elite sportswomen have shared their stories, and these are the hard truths
items.description: Low pay, discrimination, disordered eating, sexism and online abuse are just a few of the prevalent issues ABC's Elite Athletes in Women's Sport Survey has revealed, despite recent progress in women's sport.

items.title: Meta kicks 550,000 children off platforms to comply with social media ban
items.description: More than half a million Australian children have been kicked off Facebook and Instagram by Meta to comply with Australia's social media ban for under-16s.

items.title: Waltzing Matilda tribute for youngest victim of the Bondi shooting
items.description: More than 2,000 people attended a vigil for the Bondi shooting victim at the Bondi Pavilion, marking the end of the Jewish period of mourning.

items.title: The Aussie invention made famous by Queen Elizabeth II
items.description: When Queen Elizabeth II used a product on her royal tour of Australia in 1963, journalists noticed. Then everyone wanted to use it.

items.title: Firefighters were tackling a blaze when a camera alerted them to an unseen threat
items.description: As fire crews were responding to two fires on Tasmania's east coast in December, an AI camera nestled in a nearby vantage point spotted a third blaze. The early detection meant the fire was extinguished just two hours later.

items.title: Trump tells Cuba to 'make a deal' as US cuts off Venezuelan oil
items.description: The US is enforcing a strict oil blockade on Venezuela, the communist country's main supplier of oil, as the Trump administration continues to push Latin American countries to align with it.

items.title: Bulk-billing rates have almost doubled, report indicates
items.description: The percentage of GP clinics fully bulk-billing has almost doubled, according to a new report, however, the government says the data cannot be relied on.

items.title: Women forced to discuss DV cases in public at 'unsafe' outback court
items.description: Australia's domestic violence commissioner and local legal services have raised concerns about women's safety at Katherine Local Court, saying urgent upgrades are needed to protect victim-survivors.

items.title: Labor MPs apologise over 'shoot, shag or marry' game at public festival
items.description: A federal assistant minister and two Tasmanian state Labor MPs apologise after a complaint was made about their behaviour at the Taste of Summer festival in Hobart.

items.title: 'We can't survive it': The suburbs fighting against fast food giants
items.description: Nutrition, vibe and culture concerns fuel these communities that want to protect their suburbs' identity and businesses from the fast food giants.

items.title: Muslim leader and wife allegedly abused, assaulted in Melbourne
items.description: Police are investigating reports of an Islamic community leader being assaulted after he and his wife were forced off the road by a vehicle and racially abused in Dandenong South.

items.title: Man allegedly in duct tape vest charged with offensive conduct in Bondi
items.description: A man allegedly carrying a vest covered in duct-taped objects in Bondi has been arrested and charged by NSW Police, with his vest examined by the bomb disposal unit and deemed safe.
